captions.text:
Well, I guess January is still catchup 
season—or should I say, BAT-chup season! Yes,

I finally got me greasy, cumstained mitts 
on a Meta Quest 3 recently. Short review:

more powerful, still love that it&#39;s wireless, 
still hangs off the front of my face like a fat,

orphaned koala. More importantly, it allowed 
me to play that new Batman VR game everyone&#39;s

been saying is great, or at least better than the 
previous Batman VR game, which in terms of bars to

clear is a Snickers resting on two pencils. First 
impressions weren&#39;t great. I know the Batman:

Arkham series has long been grouped with Sonic the 
Hedgehog in the realm of &quot;create titles just by

jamming random words on the end of the franchise 
word,&quot; but it&#39;s still disappointing they went with

Shadow. They got it out before Assassin&#39;s Creed 
used it, at least, which is officially the point

of becoming completely hackneyed, but they cut 
it fucking fine. Anyway, in contrast to the first

Arkham VR, which was a classic tech demo-style 
early VR game, stand rooted to the spot and do

the thing that makes the next thing happen, Arkham 
Shadow is actually a full-on Arkham game, meaning

you can actually move, shock, and as well as do 
the thing that makes next things happen, do other

things that make irrelevant things happen; horror, 
astoundment, hushed whispers amid the academics.

The plot is a direct sequel to Arkham Origins, 
meaning this is the &quot;the Batman we have at home&quot;

Batman as opposed to the Conroy classic, but what 
do you want? Poor fucker&#39;s dead. Batman canon

tends to be flexible—there&#39;s, what, 12 versions 
of it in film alone, now—so here&#39;s how the dice

fell this time: Batman&#39;s parents were killed by 
Joe Chill, check, but now he was raised by Lesley

Thompkins instead of or as well as Alfred. Man, 
why&#39;d he get so hung up on the orphan thing? He

had surrogate parents queuing &#39;round the fucking 
block. He also has a nigh-brotherly relationship

with Harvey Dent growing up, so expect the 
Two-Face origin story to also get retold

for the twelveteenth time. This all has the same 
effect the Gotham TV show had on me—making me yell

questions like, &quot;Is there anyone in Batman&#39;s later 
career who DIDN&#39;T interact with Bruce Wayne as a

child?&quot; and &quot;When are Penguin and Riddler finally 
going to snog?&quot; Anyway, the plot is Gotham, the

city that has never once in its entire history not 
been in the grip of something, is in the grip of a

gang called The Rats, disenfranchised poor people 
protesting income inequality. Ooh, how relevant.

When Batman is implicated in the 
murder of a Rat who was, in fact,

committing suicide to prove a point, old 
grumpy tights starts to wonder, &quot;Huh,

maybe I need to rethink my whole approach to this; 
maybe people turn to crime because of poverty and

societal factors rather than inherent character 
flaws, and maybe that&#39;s a problem that can&#39;t be

fixed by elbow smashing their legs so their knees 
go the wrong way.&quot; And as a chorus of onlookers

cry &quot;FUCKING DUH,&quot; he vows to go undercover as a 
criminal in Blackgate Prison to both uncover the

identity of the mysterious leader the Rat King 
and gain a better understanding of the criminal

mindset. In practice, he ends up smashing an 
awful lot of legs so their knees go the wrong way,

but some of them belong to prison guards, and 
that&#39;s character growth of a sort. I suppose

there&#39;s a bit of synchronized cake ownership and 
consumption going on here as the plot wants to

follow The Batman&#39;s lead and get all chin strokey 
about societal inequality and ultimately Batman&#39;s

effectiveness as crime prevention, but it also 
wants to be larger-than-life in the established

Arkham style, so all the disaffected poor people 
have to be huge, musclebound martial artists in

rat costumes reciting revolutionary slogans 
in exaggerated New York gangster accents.

I say it&#39;s a full-on Arkham game; it&#39;s a 
stripped-down one, more a six-piece than

a 20-piece McNugget box. The main setting is 
Blackgate Prison, which isn&#39;t Arkham Asylum

but apparently shares the same interior 
designer. And many of the same prisoners,

somehow. Don&#39;t know why the fucking Joker&#39;s here; 
maybe they have an exchange program. You split

your time between being Batman investigating 
the prison after hours and undercover Bat-boss

pursuing leads on the day shift, with both modes 
providing plenty of chances to get around asshole

guards with stealth and get around asshole kneecap 
connective tissue with elbow smashes. The freeflow

combat translates relatively well to VR; you&#39;ll 
hate it if you&#39;re one of those people who turned

the counter icons off in the other games because 
sometimes, this is like Batman&#39;s mask got infected

with Spyware there&#39;s so many indicators, from 
countering to picking targets to punching the

little glowing circles to finish a dude off. 
Still, Arkham combat has always been about the

sheer satisfaction of Batman&#39;s punches colliding 
with the sound of freight trains ploughing into

orphanages, and that&#39;s all the more intensified 
when you&#39;re physically punching the air.

I could never land critical strikes in the other 
games, but I can here because they depend on how

hard you hit rather than timing, and I always 
get slightly embarrassingly into the VR motions

because I can tell myself it counts as exercise. 
The translation of the stealthy predator stuff

is a little wobblier because something seems to 
have gone wrong with the guard&#39;s pathfinding,

I&#39;d string one up on a gargoyle and then have to 
sit up in the rafters doing today&#39;s Bat-Wordle

while I wait for the other guards to stop milling 
around beneath them, trying to scratch their itchy

bums on the handrail. Also, the way you have to 
spread your arms to do a cape glide is pathetic,

frankly; every time I do it, I feel like a 
severely unmotivated Dracula impersonator. It

rarely took on the first attempt, and I have long 
arms; I kept misjudging my position in my play

space and smashing my hands into walls, furniture, 
and small dogs. Besides all that, the stealth is

functional, if, again, a little stripped down to 
accommodate all the extra fiddliness of VR, like

when you fail to use a batarang in a tight spot 
because you didn&#39;t pinch your fingers in front

of your chest in precisely the desired manner. So 
that&#39;s core gameplay; there&#39;s also side objectives

and collectibles; you have rat statues instead of 
Riddler trophies, but there&#39;s no real benefit to

glean besides completionism and the fun sound they 
make when you fling them at a wall. You don&#39;t even

get to punch the Riddler in the face at the end of 
it and ruin his future Penguin snogging prospects.

But if you want to talk about what I find 
generally disappointing about Arkham Shadow,

it&#39;s the lack of that unique Batman Arkham 
fantastical streak. You run into Two-Face,

Scarecrow, and Harley Quinn, but all in 
pre-villainy phases of their lives, so

they&#39;re basically all just dudes. Dudes with jobs. 
The closest thing to a classic Arkham over-the-top

supervillain fight is against some nobody prison 
guard who&#39;s inexplicably 10 feet tall; again,

a dude with a job. There&#39;s also an obnoxiously 
hard fight against a mob boss where you have to

split your attention between punching goons, 
planting bombs, and flinging batarangs at a

dude with a minigun, and while firing the 
minigun probably isn&#39;t the dude&#39;s job,

he&#39;s certainly an enthusiastic hobbyist. 
Alright, fine, the third and only other boss

fight is against a giant hallucination monster 
Batman, but that doesn&#39;t score points because

Suicide Squad did the same fucking thing, and 
that&#39;s like copying from the exam paper of the

remedial student who it turns out all along 
was writing on a square of used toilet paper.
